title: Projects
text:
Master’s Thesis (ongoing) — Conceptual & Psychometric Foundations of Socio-Emotional Skills (BESSI)


Topic: Psychometric validation of a short-form instrument to assess socio-emotional skills in adolescents.


Content: In my master’s thesis, I investigate the conceptual and psychometric foundations of socio-emotional skills measurement, focusing on the distinction between skills (“I can”) and personality traits (“I am”). The project examines whether high correlations reflect substantive overlap or near-synonymous item wording.


Methods:



Large longitudinal sample of upper secondary students


Exploratory Structural Equation Modeling (ESEM)


Longitudinal measurement invariance testing


Latent stability models


R (lavaan), FIML for missing data





Secondary Analysis — ITT & CACE effects in a digital socio-emotional intervention


Topic: Compliance-sensitive causal effects in a digital socio-emotional intervention for preschool children.


Content: Secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial. Beyond intention-to-treat (ITT), I applied Complier Average Causal Effect (CACE) models to examine how intervention effects depend on actual usage (compliance).


Methods:



Secondary analysis of an RCT


ITT vs. CACE comparison


FIML for missing data


Sensitivity and tipping-point analyses



Key contribution: ITT effects were small/absent, while CACE estimates suggested stronger effects among high-compliance participants and highlighted threats to causal interpretation when design assumptions are weak.




Experimental Study — Epistemic emotions and information-seeking


Topic: Epistemic emotions, misinformation, and exploratory information-seeking.


Content: In an online experiment, we tested whether stylistic framings of refutation texts induce epistemic emotions (confusion vs. situational interest) and influence exploratory information-seeking behaviour and comprehension.


Methods:



Online experiment (between-subjects)


Manipulation via text design


Behavioural measure (click behaviour)


Regression models, ANOVA, robustness checks



Key contribution: No clear condition differences, but the study provides a methodological analysis of limits in emotion induction and click-based proxies.




Bachelor’s Thesis — Mediation model of mindfulness, decentering, and emotional competence


Topic: Do decentering and emotional competence mediate the relationship between mindfulness and well-being?


Content: In my bachelor’s thesis, I examined whether the relationship between mindfulness and well-being can be explained by underlying mechanisms, specifically decentering and emotional competence. Using cross-sectional survey data, I tested a mediation model to explore potential indirect pathways.


Methods:



Online survey study (N = 190)


Mediation analysis using PROCESS (Hayes)


Bootstrapping (5,000 iterations)


Path analysis (SPSS AMOS)


A priori power analysis



Key contribution: While causal interpretation was limited due to the correlational design, the project introduced a mechanistic perspective on socio-emotional competencies and highlighted the need for experimental and compliance-sensitive approaches in subsequent work.

title: Projects
text:
Conceptual and Psychometric Foundations of Socio-Emotional Skills (BESSI)
Topic:
Psychometric validation of a short-form instrument to assess socio-emotional skills in adolescents.
Content:
In my master’s thesis, I investigate the conceptual and psychometric foundations of socio-emotional skills measurement, using the German 45-item version of the Behavioral, Emotional, and Social Skills Inventory (BESSI-G). A central focus of the thesis is the theoretical distinction between skills and personality traits, particularly the question of whether skill measures capture functional capacities (“I can”) or merely rephrase trait-like tendencies (“I am”).
Building on recent critiques of semantic redundancy in personality and skills research, the thesis examines whether high correlations between skills and traits reflect substantive overlap or arise from near-synonymous item wording. Rather than treating correlations as evidence for construct equivalence, the project approaches this issue from a measurement perspective, emphasizing construct definition, item semantics, and factorial structure.
Methodologically, the thesis employs longitudinal psychometric models to assess the factorial structure and measurement invariance of the BESSI-G across time, providing a necessary precondition for interpreting change, stability, and intervention effects in socio-emotional competencies.
Methods:

Large longitudinal sample of upper secondary students
Exploratory Structural Equation Modeling (ESEM)
WSMLV vs. ML
Longitudinal measurement invariance testing
Latent stability models
R (lavaan), FIML for missing data

title: Projects
section: Secondary Analysis of a Randomized Intervention
text:
Secondary Analysis of a Randomized Intervention
Topic:
Compliance-sensitive causal effects in a digital socio-emotional intervention for preschool children.
Content:
I conducted a secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial evaluating a digital socio-emotional training program for preschoolers. Beyond standard intention-to-treat (ITT) analyses, I applied Complier Average Causal Effect (CACE) models to examine how intervention effects depend on actual usage (compliance).
Methods:

Secondary analysis of an RCT
ITT vs. CACE comparison
FIML for missing data
Sensitivity and tipping-point analyses

Key contribution:
While ITT effects were small or absent, CACE analyses revealed stronger effects among high-compliance participants. At the same time, the study critically discusses design-related threats to causal inference (e.g., resentful demoralization, control group issues), illustrating the limits of statistical corrections when design assumptions are violated.

title: Projects
text:
Experimental Study on Epistemic Emotions
Topic:
Epistemic emotions, misinformation, and exploratory information-seeking.
Content:
In an experimental online study, we investigated whether stylistic framings of refutation texts induce epistemic emotions (confusion vs. situational interest) and thereby influence exploratory information-seeking behavior and text comprehension.
Methods:

Online experiment (between-subjects)
Manipulation of epistemic emotions via text design
Behavioral measure of information seeking (click behavior)
Regression models, ANOVA, non-parametric robustness checks

Key contribution:
The study did not find significant differences between conditions, but offers a detailed methodological analysis of why subtle text framings may be insufficient to manipulate epistemic emotions. The work highlights challenges in emotion induction, retrospective measurement, and the limitations of click-based proxies for information seeking.

title: About
text:
Master’s Student | Empirical Educational Research & Educational Psychology
University of Tübingen (Expected graduation: October 2026)
I study how socio-emotional and self-regulatory competencies can be defined, measured, and causally interpreted in educational contexts—especially when real-world research designs limit what conclusions are justified.









Note



Quick facts
- M.Sc. Empirical Educational Research (Tübingen)
- Focus: assessment & evaluation of socio-emotional competencies
- Tools: R · Quarto · SPSS · MAXQDA · JATOS





I am interested in how socio-emotional and self-regulatory competencies can be conceptually defined, validly measured, and causally interpreted in educational contexts.
These competencies are widely considered important for educational success and democratic participation, yet their measurement and evaluation pose substantial methodological challenges.





My methodological focus lies in quantitative research designs and psychometric approaches, including the evaluation of measurement models, longitudinal analyses, and experimental interventions.
I work primarily with reproducible workflows in R and Quarto.

Quantitative methodsQualitative methodsResearch practiceScientific communication



Quantitative data analysis in R
Measurement models & psychometrics (e.g., factor models; measurement invariance)
Experimental and quasi-experimental evaluation (e.g., ITT / CACE in secondary analyses)
Longitudinal data analysis and missing data handling (e.g., FIML)




Qualitative content analysis following Mayring
Category development based on interview material (East/West Germany)
Coding and analysis using MAXQDA
Identification and structuring of stereotype-related narratives




Reproducible reporting with Quarto
Structured project coordination and independent workflow management
Teaching assistance in statistics (Master-level tutorial support)
Preparation of empirical materials, reports, and presentations




Audience-oriented explanation of methodological concepts
Clear and structured presentation of empirical findings
Development of teaching and presentation materials with focus on clarity







I intend to pursue a PhD focusing on the measurement and evaluation of socio-emotional competencies and the development of empirically grounded assessment tools.
